The head of the character grows disproportionally and a nightmarish face appears at the back of it. The character can cast the spell detect thoughts once per long rest. Charisma is its spellcasting ability for the spell. Flaw: The character suffers from a short-term madness.

Balefire, harmless blue and green flames, sometimes runs down the skin of the character. The characters knows the fire bolt cantrip. Charisma is its spellcasting ability for the spell. Flaw: Flammable objects that aren't being worn or carried within 30 feet of the character catch fire.
The Warp Touch stops. The character keeps all previously acquired mutations but is cured of the disease.

entries.name: Lure Weed
entries: Lure weed is a mutated plant that only grows in water sources tainted by Warpstone. The weed itself is easy to spot, with a long stem ending on bioluminescent leaves. While the weed itself is pleasing to look at, its true value lies in the remedy that can be brewed out of it.

items.name: Warp Touch Remedy:
items.entry: A character that has proficiency with Alchemist's Tools or Herbalism Kit, and access to the proper equipment, can prepare a remedy with lure weed flowers. The remedy has a value of 40gp when it comes to crafting (see crafting rules p.187 of the Player's Handbook). Once ingested, the Warp Touch stops. The character keeps all previously acquired mutations but is cured of the disease.

variantrule.name: Wraith Extra Powers
entries: Ghost and wraith were once people, with their own personalities, dreams, hopes and flaws. When they died some of their abilities carried in undeath. You can add the following Innate Spellcasting options to any kind of ghost, specters or wraith to make it more unique. These abilities are affecting the CR of the creature as indicated. Please note that, in some case, the ability might be more powerful or useful when combined with some other feature already included in the creature's profile. To know the spell DC of the powers refer yourself to the Spell DC table.

entries.name: Entropy
entries: By essence, ghost are entropic creatures, forces of decay infused with necrotic energies. The creature can use the {@spell bestow curse}, {@spell ray of enfeeblement} and {@spell vampiric touch} spells once per short rest.

entries.name: Gravetouched
entries: Unexplainable cold spots are often associated with haunted places and many ghost do have the power to summon supernatural cold. The creature can use the ray of frost cantrip at will and the sleet storm and cone of cold spells once per short rest.

entries.name: Madness
entries: Many ghosts are utturly mad, driven insane by an eternity in constant sorrow. Some of them have the ability to project that madness. The creature can use the {@spell crown of madness}, {@spell confusion} and {@spell fear} spells once per short rest.

entries.name: Supernatural Lockdown
entries: The creature is able to lockdown a place, preventing anyone to enter or leave it without powerful magic. The ghost can use the spell {@spell arcane lock} at will and the {@spell mordenkainen's private sanctum} and {@spell wall of force} spells once per short rest.

entries.name: Telekinesis
entries: Many ghost have the ability to move object and people with the sheer strength of their will. The creature can use the cantrip {@spell mage hand} at will and the spell {@spell telekinesis} once per short rest.

entries.name: Ubiquitous
entries: Some ghost are known to haunt multiple places at once, or to be able to appear instantly from a location to another, even when separated by great distances. The creature can use the {@spell simulacrum} and {@spell teleport} spell once per short rest to move between places related to its story.

entries.name: Warp
entries: Many ghosts have the ability to manipulate reality, shapping it to reflect the constant pain they are experiencing. The creature can use the {@spell animate object}, {@spell seeming} and {@spell silence} spells once per short rest.

entries.name: Genesis of Evil
entries: What makes a villain? Some people are simply born with the seed of evil in them, subject to dark urges from the very moment they are born. Others are unable to relay to others, fundamentally broken and committing terrible acts without even blinking. However, very few people are born truly evil, most reacted to the way society shaped them and motivated their acts, others were forged by circumstances that scared them deeply, sending them spiraling down a dark abyss or were simply bent on survival, no matter the cost. Often, inside each villain there is a victim, but some simply say that you either die a hero, or live long enough to see yourself become the villain...

entries.name: The Grand Plan
entries: Characters appearing in this section are villains centralized around a theme and made to be used as evolving antagonists, progressing alongside the party. They work as individual or organization, each of them has a Grand Plan and smaller schemes to reach it. The Grand Plan will likely change in scope, as the villain's reality and ambition evolve with its power and capacities. A low CR villain is more focused on the local affairs, while a high CR villain will likely affect an entire nation, or even the entire campaign world.

entries.name: Mounting Threat
entries: Villains or groups of villains don't typically sit in their lair doing nothing or waiting patiently for the party to come and find them. This type of behavior might be suited for some individuals, but most villains will pursue their own agenda, however basic or elaborate it may be. As the party progresses, so does their foe. Each time the party completes an important quest, takes an extended rest period or completes a story arch, roll or choose on the scheme table what scheme the villain is currently trying to achieve (or its organization and agents, if any). If the party learns of their scheme, it could be a great opportunity for them to interfere.

Parts of this section are revolving around the idea that your villain(s) will face the party multiples times and increase in power. This requires preparation, as players may go for your main antagonist earlier than you expected and try to get rid of them for good. Clever or instinctive villains will not let themselves be cornered if they can avoid it and will have several escape plans once the odds turn against them. If you opt for an organization of villains this is less of a challenge, as killing a specific individual or destroying a location might not be enough to end the threat.

Consider a few potential means of escape for your villain before an encounter, using magic (teleportation, illusion, invisibility, darkness spells, scrolls or potions) or mundane means (planned cave-in, secret passage, reinforcements, risky path where the party might hesitate to follow, etc.). If your villain does fall, it is not necessarily their end, especially for villains with allies that have access to resurrection magic or serve a powerful master.

entries.caption: Scheme
rows: {@i Distract (roll again for its true scheme)} - Threatens player's assets, allies or loved ones; Unleash seemingly random danger and mayhem; Destabilizes opposed government or faction; Acquires/establishes fake new lair; Makes a public appearance and demonstration of its power.

{@i Strengthen} - Recruits multiple hirelings or a highly skilled ally; Infiltrates/corrupts a spy in an opposed faction; Acquires a useful magic item; Destroy/attacks a rival faction; Develop the defenses of its lair.
{@i Progress} - Works towards the next step of its Grand Plan. See each section for suggested Grand Plan ideas.

{@i Setback} - A part of the villain's past is unwittingly revealed; An ally of the villain is killed or betrays them; A natural or magical disaster damages the villain's lair; A hint of the villain's Great Plan is revealed; Unforeseen complications prevent the villain to accomplish anything.
